title: Ticket #1348: Updating the granularity of accepts per cycle through event loop
description:
When updating the maximum accepts per cycle through the event loop we notice a significant increase in the performance of the schedd.

Test: 3000 slots 100K 60 second sleep jobs

When MAX_ACCEPTS_PER_CYCLE=1 ~27 jobs/sec

When MAX_ACCEPTS_PER_CYCLE=0 <-accept all inbound connections ~277 jobs/sec - a ten fold increase. We are still performing more test, but this is a dramatic increase in performance.
remarks:
2010-Apr-14 14:20:12 by tannenba:
Curious of the above numbers are timings for entire lifecycle of the job, or just job launches.

My worry is if we are we robbing peter to pay paul --- seems like the performance gain is happening at a fundamental level by raising the priority of command handler callbacks -vs- everything else. It certainly was the intent of daemonCore to round-robin across all events, and this patch brings us closer to the original intent. But I worry a bit at what the cost of this will be - e.g. if the schedd is spending more time on command callbacks, are reaper callbacks going to be more starved and thus we'll see a pile up of unreaped shadow pids? On the other hand, perhaps what is being deprioritized are timer callbacks which are firing too often anyway (because nobody ever thought hard about how they should be tuned/set), all is good in the hood.

Perhaps ultimately priority of different callbacks handlers should be tuned for different workloads.

2010-Apr-14 14:24:48 by tannenba:
All in all I really like what Tim unearthed here... A rather subtle change that has a much more profound impact than anyone would have ever guessed. Nice sleuth work Tim!!!

2010-Apr-14 14:38:02 by tstclair:
This is the average when it bursts, before it fills your pool.

The overall throughput is significantly higher, we still need to have a direct comparison, but the total time to complete 100K jobs decreased significantly.

2010-Apr-14 14:55:14 by danb:
Yup, this is good stuff. I'm very curious to find out whether this is helping by changing the relative priority of the command socket or whether it is helping by simply getting more work done per iteration of the event loop: i.e. making accept() higher priority or reducing overhead per accept(). If the latter, then it may be time to think about alternatives to select().

2010-Apr-16 15:08:34 by tstclair:
Unless there is any objection I plan to merge, by default the behaviour should be the same, and by changing the param one can adjust.

2010-Apr-17 17:41:00 by danb:
For what it's worth: in my test environment, MAX_ACCEPTS_PER_CYCLE=0 produces a job completion rate that is 1.1x to 1.2x the rate with MAX_ACCEPTS_PER_CYCLE=1. I was hoping to see a bit more! Now I am curious to know what the actual throughput was in the environment at RedHat. My test machine is not particularly powerful (32-bit dual core 2.4GHz).

As expected, MAX_ACCEPTS_PER_CYCLE=0 noticeably reduces shadow --> schedd communication failures, indicating that these communication failures are caused by starvation of the command socket.

My tests were based on the head of the master branch, so pre-7.5.3.

2010-Apr-18 10:17:59 by matt:
Will you both add info about your methodology?

2010-Apr-18 19:41:56 by danb:
I used 1s sleep jobs instead of 60s sleep jobs and I only submitted 20k. Here's my submit file: 

executable = /bin/sleep
arguments = 1
notification = never
requirements = (Arch == "INTEL" || Arch == "X86_64")
should_transfer_files = yes
when_to_transfer_output = on_exit
transfer_executable = false
queue 20000

I then measured the time it took from the time the first job started to the time the last one finished. The jobs ran on the UW ghost pool. Because of the limited amount of memory on my test submit machine, I set MAX_JOBS_RUNNING=2000 instead of 3000.

I tried two different configurations: one with SPOOL on a local disk and one SPOOL in /dev/shm. The speedup in job throughput from setting MAX_ACCEPTS_PER_CYCLE=0 was about 1.1x in the first case and 1.2x in the second case.

2010-Apr-19 09:04:11 by tstclair:
So matt's comment is a good one. We should probably start to note the following:

==Preconditions: (Going to start using wallaby to store exact info)==

1.) 6 8-way over-provisioned nodes using layering(glide ins) to make it appear that we have ~ 3k nodes.

2.) SPOOL -> local drive /var/lib/condor/spool

3.) Our submit file is pretty much the same expect we queue 100000

==What & How we are measuring:==

The job spawning rate by the schedd, using a series of scripts to parse the history log and the user job logs.

==Results:==

We see a huge spike in how fast the schedd to spawn jobs, but despite this fact, we see a saw tooth graph on pool utilization which points to another source of down time, which we suspect it likely due to negotiation (or some sub optimal configuration)
